etymologies: mid 18th century; earliest use found in Horace Walpole (1717–1797), author, politician, and patron of the arts. From French hennin, henin, of uncertain origin; perhaps from early modern Dutch henninck cockerel, rooster, with allusion to the resemblance of the headdress to a cock's comb, although the Dutch word is first recorded later than the French and evidence for its use to denote a headdress has not been found

definitions: A name given to a type of woman's headdress worn in the 15th century, especially in France, consisting of a cone (or truncated cone) with a fine veil hanging from the top; also applied to a similar high headdress extending to two conical points. Occasionally (and in earliest use) also: a type of headdress worn in Burgundy and Flanders in the 15th century, of uncertain design.

notes.text: The original name given to the various designs of conical headdress is unknown; they are so called due to the (probably mistaken) belief that hennin denoted one or more of these.
